ngiemboon: Mèŋ n da gíŋ ńgyá tsɔ́ ngʉ̀ngʉ̀ gie ee ndùmo ssé tsetsáʼ, é gwɔ́ ngʉ̀ngʉ̀ gie e pǔ ńjÿó nyìŋ mesoŋ ntsèm.
en: Here is a tragedy I have observed under the sun,   and it weighs heavily on humanity:  # 6:1 Or it is common among men

ngiemboon: Mé gyá tsɔ̌ nyìŋ gwɔ́ ndùmo Ssé tsetsáʼ ńgwɔ́ gẅie Ssé la gÿo á gwɔ́ ngàŋa mmó, ńgẅiin shúm fùʼ, mé piŋ ńgÿo mekùʼ mé. À te zága tsɔ́ mmó na shúm sie à tsɔ̌ɔn wɔ́, tá Ssé te nyé yé á zẅɛ́ʼɛ fùʼ yé wɔ́. Atsɔ̌ nyìŋ ndyɛ̀ʼɛ zɔ̌ zẅɛ́ʼ. Yɛ̌ gwɔ́ pɔ́ fÿɔ́g sẅɛ̀ɛ, ńgwɔ́ máa ngʉ̀ngʉ̀ gie e kúu nyìŋ.
en: God gives a person riches, wealth, and honor   so that he lacks nothing of all he desires for himself,  # 6:2 Ps 17:14; 73:7 but God does not allow him to enjoy them. Instead, a stranger will enjoy them. This is futile and a sickening tragedy.

ngiemboon: Nyìŋ zɔɔn ńgwɔ́ péʼe ńzyé púɔ mbàŋa tà é gwɔ́ nkÿo, ḿbiŋ ńnéŋe tsɛ̀ɛ njÿó na mengùʼ tà é gyɔ́ɔn, melyɛʼɛ́ láʼ mé pú ńgyɔ́ɔn pɔ́ lêkɔ́ wɔ́ɔ, á piŋ te néŋe tsɛ̀ɛ lepòŋ tà ńzẅɛ́ wɔ́, ńkwé, à te lesyè gẅiin, mbà n dɔgɔ ńgyá yɔ́ɔn ngie atsege múɔ cʉa yé.
en: A man may father a hundred children and live many years. No matter how long he lives,   if he is not satisfied by good things and does not even have a proper burial,  # 6:3 Is 14:20; Jr 8:2; 22:19 I say that a stillborn child is better off than he.  # 6:3 Jb 3:16; Ec 4:3

ngiemboon: Á zɔɔn ńgwɔ́ ngie múɔ ŋwɛ́ ka tó yé tsɛ̀ɛ njÿó pɔ́ páʼ fèfà gẅie á cʉ̌a, à piŋ ńgee tsɛ̀ɛ nzěm, nzěm ne ńtóo ḿvéle lezíŋ sé.
en: For he comes in futility and he goes in darkness, and his name is shrouded in darkness.

ngiemboon: À la te gyá tsɔ́ lyɛ̌ʼ njÿó wɔ́, ńké te zsé mmó gie lyɛʼɛ́ láʼ áa yɛ̌ wɔ́. À gẅiin sẅétè ńcʉa nyìŋ gẅie à kà néŋe tsɛ̀ɛ njÿó tɛʼ.
en: Though a stillborn child does not see the sun and is not conscious, it has more rest than he.

ngiemboon: Wɔɔn nyìŋ ŋwɛ́ lɔɔn ńzɔɔn ńnéŋe pɔ́ ngùʼ ntsáʼ pʉ̀a, ńké te gẅiin lepòŋ wɔ́, mbà á ge kẅéte yé na kɔ́, á nue kɔ̀ɔkɔ́ɔ wɔ́ɔ zsote pɔ́ tsɛ̀ɛ legwé.
en: And if a person lives a thousand years twice, but does not experience happiness, do not both go to the same place?

ngiemboon: Nyìŋ mesoŋ faʼ mefàʼ ntsèm pɔ́ lélɔg ńgÿo yé mmó gie à kwoŋ. Táʼ, à kě laa zẅɛ́ɛ tsɔ́ mmó wɔ́.
en: All of a person’s labor is for his stomach,  ,# 6:7 Pr 16:26

ngiemboon: Anzsènò lɔgɔ kɔ́ ńcʉa gʉ̀gʉ̀ nyìŋ? Ambóŋ zíʼi lénéŋe tsetsɛ̀ɛ pʉ̀a mesoŋ mboŋó péʼe, á kẅéte yé na kɔ́?
en: What advantage then does the wise person have over the fool?   What advantage is there for the poor person who knows how to conduct himself before others?

ngiemboon: Áa mbòŋ mbwó nyìŋ lékága na mmó gie à gẅiin, ńcʉa nkwaŋá wé létyé na shúm sie à neŋé ńtsɔ́ɔn, yɛ̌ e gíŋ ńgwɔ́ pɔ́ fÿɔ́g sẅɛ̀ɛ, ńgɔɔn léjwoŋte fèfà.
en: Better what the eyes see than wandering desire.   This too is futile and a pursuit of the wind.  # 6:9 Or a feeding on wind, or an affliction of spirit,# 6:9 Ec 1:14

ngiemboon: Akɔ̀ɔkɔ́ɔ wɔ́ɔ gie áa wó, mé la láʼ ńzsé lezíŋ, pege piŋ ńzsé mmó gie nyìŋ mesoŋ aa yɛ̌, à te kuʼu légwɔ́ gie pɔ́ nyìŋ gẅie à tʉ̀ ńcʉa yé, zoŋo tsɔ́ mmó wɔ́.
en: Whatever exists was given its name long ago,  ,# 6:10 Gn 2:19; Ec 1:9–10; 3:15 and it is known what mankind is. But he is not able to contend with the one stronger than he.  # 6:10 Jb 9:32; Is 45:9

ngiemboon: Nyìŋ lɔɔn shwóŋe tɛʼ, mbà à ge gɔɔn menò tà ńgyɔ́ɔn mie é té tyé, à shwoŋé púʼu, ńjÿó yɛ̌ pì?
en: For when there are many words, they increase futility.   What is the advantage for mankind?

ngiemboon: Awɔ̌ zsé mmó gie á póŋo nyìŋ mesoŋ á tsɛ̀ɛ we legwɔ́ wó, á na mé melyɛ̌ʼ mie é gwɔ́ pɔ́ fÿɔ́g sẅɛ̀ɛ gie é cʉa páʼ majʉ́jʉ́ŋ? Ngwɔ́ wɔ̌ shwóŋo yé mmó gie á ge láʼ cʉa, á fʉ̀ʼ gie à te gíŋ ńgwɔ́ ndùmo ssé tsetsáʼ wɔ́?
en: For who knows what is good for anyone in life, in the few days of his futile life that he spends like a shadow?   Who can tell anyone what will happen after him under the sun?
